title: easyjet-flights-abroad---destination-list-july-1
story: EasyJet is to beginhundreds more international flights from airports across the UK from next week.The airline said it will restart the international and domestic flights from Wednesday, July , as it also secured a major cash injection to bolster its finances in the face of the pandemic.Where will EasyJet fly to Holidaymakers will be able to fly from  airports across the UK to a number of countries including France, Spainand Italy.From the start of next month, it will run around  flights each day across Europe, including over  flights a week to and from the UK.On June , it restarted a ldquosmall number of flights for the first time since its aircraft were grounded in March.EasyJet said it plans to fly about half of its , routes in July, before increasing to about  per centin August.Air bridges will be available from next weekThe announcement follows reports that air bridges will be available from next week to allow Britons to take holidays in other countries without quarantining for  days.The UK Government will finalise agreements in coming days to allow people to travel from the UK to a small number of countries including Spain, France and Greece - according to reporting by The Times, The Sun and The Daily .What hasEasyJet said Robert Carey, chiefcommercial and strategy officer, said: ldquoWe are really pleased to be relaunching even more of our flights from  July and starting to get customers away on their much-needed summer holidays.ldquoOf course, the safety and wellbeing of our customers and crew remains our highest priority.ldquoThis is why we have implemented a number of measures enhancing safety at each part of the journey from disinfecting the aircraft to requiring customers and crew to wear masks.What are easyJets rules for passengers These are the rules that travelers must follow:On-board measures:All passengersand crew will be required to wear masks onboard at all times. Initially when flights restart, the Bistro and Boutique service will not be available. Furthermore, all flights will be equipped with spare sanitary equipment including masks, gloves and hand sanitiser to ensure these are available to customers and crew at all times onboard,required.easyJetrsquos aircraft are already fitted with state of art filtration technology. High efficiency particle arresting filters filter . per cent of airborne contaminants in the cabin, including viruses and bacteria. These filters are the same as those used in hospitals and through them the cabin air gets replaced every - minutes.Airport measures:To protect passengers and ground crew in the airport, passengers will be able to use the automated bag drop to check in their hold luggage and screens will be in place at our check in desks and at airports where auto bag drop is not available. Ground crew and cabin will not handle any customer documents during boarding so customers will be asked to present and scan their own documents.easyJet already encourages all customers to check in online and download their boarding pass onto their smart phone or to print their own boarding passes before arriving at the airport. Ground crew will also wear gloves and masks at all times when transporting customer luggage to and from the aircraft.Social distancing:Passengers will be able to practice social distancing in the airports, at gates and during boarding. Onboard, and where possible, crew will invite passengers to sit at distancefrom those not in their partywhere seats are available.,params: .pushEasyJet says it will continue to work with the relevant national authorities to review and assess what measures are required in the longer term.

title: air-bridges-destinations-might-included
story: Travellers couldbe jetting off abroad on quarantine-free summer holidays soon - withthe UK Government set to announce so-called air bridges to popular destinations.Since March , the Foreign and Commonwealth Office advised British nationals against all but essential international travel.Now, a number of short-haul flights to European countries are expected to resume from next month in a bid to kick-start the tourist economy.This is what you need to know about air bridges and travelling abroad.What are air bridges Also known as travel corridors, air bridges will allow Britons to go on holiday to certain destinations without needing to quarantine for  days on theirto the UK.Which countries are likely to be included The Government is expected to announce next week Britainrsquos first air bridges with ldquolow-risk European destinations, including France, Italy, Spain, Greece and Germany.According to reports, air bridges will be announced in batches, with the second set of destinations likely to include other European countries such as Denmark, Norway, Finland and Holland and ldquolow-risk Caribbean islands.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said air bridges would only be agreed with countries which have a coronavirus test and trace system of the same standard as that used in Britain.When will air bridges be introduced The first air bridges to low-risk countries could be in force from July , but Mr Shapps said no announcement will be made until June  when the quarantine measures will be officially reviewed.Which countries are unlikely to be included There were mixed reports over whether Portugal would be included in the UKrsquos plans next week after a spike in coronavirus cases in the country.Long-haul flights to destinations such as Vietnam, Singapore, Hong Kong are reportedly not expected before late summer.Flights to Australia are thought to be more complicated due to the need to stop over in other countries, which increases the risk of contracting or spreading coronavirus.What are the rules on quarantine Since June , all passengers ndash bar a handful of exemptions ndash have been required to go into self-isolation for  days when they arrive in the UK.People who fail to comply can be fined pound, in England, and police are allowed to use ldquoreasonable force to make sure they follow the rules.What measures have airports taken Last month, Heathrow Airport began trialling thermal screening technology to detect elevated temperatures of arriving passengers.Edinburgh Airport has implemented a colour-coded one-way system to maintain social distancing, while protective screens have been installed at check-in, security and arrivals, and staff wear face coverings and personal protective equipmentin ldquopassenger-facing areas.At Gatwick Airport, hand sanitiser stations, protective screens, regular deep cleaning and social distancing instructions have been introduced throughout the site, with face mask vending machines selling four masks for pound.Pre-booked airport security slots are being trialled at Manchester Airport, in which passengers can reserve a free -minute window to use a dedicated lane taking them directly to a checkpoint.

title: find-man-king-street
story: HAILED by their neighbours as the gardening ldquoKing and Queen, a Peebles couple have spent decades transforming the grass verges on their street into an attractive wildle haven.lsquoIf you want something done right, do it yourselfrsquo ndash an age-old adage that was brought to le by Brian Elliot and his we Lynne.The King of Kingsway, , moved to the street in .When Scottish Borders Council stopped cutting the steep grass banking outside his home, he and his neighbour Billy Duncan rolled up their sleeves and got on with the job.That was  years ago, and Billy has since moved, but green-fingered Brian continues to develop the plantation garden, with many comparing it to the beauty of Dawyckrsquos botanical garden.If the display were in the running at the prestigious RHS Cha Flower Show, judges would go wild for the attractive shrubs and nectar-rich flowers, which grab the attention of bees and butterflies.But Kingswayrsquos Monty Don has not only created a garden that is pleasing to the eye, he has also built a home for wildle.ldquoOver the years Irsquove planted a iety of shrubs, trees and bushes and flowers and put bark down," he said."Itrsquos a great habitat for insects which encourages birds."We get lots of butterflies, bees and itrsquos a wee haven for hedgehogs."Itrsquos just lovely hearing the birds singing and the bees buzzing."The -year-old says his nature reserve is appreciated by many in the town.Having created the garden and maintained it for  years, we asked Brianit is a labour of love.He laughed: ldquoI donrsquot like gardening ndash itrsquos a chore."At least thatrsquos what I tell people when they stop to speak."Neighbours and locals passing by do appreciate it, which makes it worthwhile.The garden, which spans over  metres, hasnrsquot cost Brian an arm and a leg ndash just his big toe!ldquoIt was  years ago. Irsquod just come back from holiday and had my sandals on."I went out to cut the grass and slipped down the banking and cut off my big toe, he explained.ldquoIt was my own stupid fault. I shouldrsquove put my safety boots on. I learned a valuable lesson that day.Brianrsquos efforts were recognised in  when he received the Letime Achievement Award from Peebles in Bloom.You could call Brian the king of lsquoungardeningrsquo. Rather than creating a controlled environment with a perfectly manicured lawn full of chemicals and pesticides, he has brought back the beauty of wilderness and reversed the ecological decline.He has built a home for the local wildle which has Peebles residents and birds singing in symphony.

story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas raised a flag to mark Armed Forces Day .The UK has observed Armed Forces Day since ndash although Veterans Day existed before that.Councillor John Greenwell said: "I am delighted that SBC is once again supporting our armed forces during these dficult times."Mr Greenwell, the councils "champion for armed forces and veterans", said coronavirus-related restrictions meant the the occasion could not be marked "in the usual way".He added: "SBC has always been at the forefront in supporting our armed forces, recognising our historical connections and commitments made by many Borderers over the years."Even just now we are grateful for their efforts in running the regionrsquos mobile COVID- testing centre."I look forward to being able to celebrate Armed Forces Week next year in a more traditional way."Due to social-distancing restrictions, many events and parades have been cancelled across the UK.

title: mobile-testing-boosted-largest-armed-forces-deployment-pandemic
story: The UKrsquos mobile testing unit capacity is to be boosted by the largest deployment of armed forces personnel during the Covid- outbreak.An additional  Department of Health and Social Carevehicles will be made available across the country, bringing the number of mobile testing units to , up from  at the end of April.A further , armed forces personnel will be tasked with providing support to the units.According to the Ministry of Defence , this will represent the largest deployment of personnel in support of the Governmentrsquos response to the coronavirus crisis, with a total of , involved.The increase in support will be phased in over several weeks, the MoD said.So far military personnel have staffed , mobile testing unit sites, helping to complete more than , tests.The MoD said personnel had also helped deliver home testing kits to care homes and operate regional testing sites before they were handed over to commercial operators.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said: ldquoTesting is at the heart of the strategy for beating coronavirus.ldquoThe UK armed forces have played a vital role in ensuring that key workers and the most vulnerable are able to access that testing where and when they need it most.ldquoOur military will continue to support however possible and for as long as needed, in order to keep the British people safe as lockdown measures are adjusted.Mobile facilities, which can be set up in under  minutes, allow for testing capacity to reach across the UK, particularly remote locations.Armed forces personnel collect swabs at the mobile sites, which are then sent to labs for processing..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Mobile testing boosted by largest armed forces deployment during pandemic

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: floral-display-gains-tv-stars-seal-approval
story: TV presenter and naturalist Chris Packham praised the colourful planting surrounding the townrsquos iconic golf ball sculpture at the Levenhall roundabout, which contains a mix of Scottish wildflowers.Species include yarrow, cornflower, wild carrot, viperrsquos bugloss, corn marigold, hawkbit, ox-eye daisy, corn poppy, cowslip, primrose, meadow buttercup, yellow rattle, hedge woundwort, devilrsquos-bit scabious and dandelion.Referring to a video of the display on social media, Mr Packham, the co-presenter of the BBCrsquos nature programmes Springwatch, Autumnwatch and Winterwatch, tweeted: ldquoEvery council across the UK should aspire to this ndash itrsquos beautul and productive and what people want from a new normal for wildle and the environment. Top work Musselburgh!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoIn recent years, East Lothian Council has created and managed a number of wildflower sites across the county to increase bioersity within towns and villages.ldquoThe wildflowers currently visible at the roundabout on Haddington Road, Musselburgh, have self-seeded from previous yearsrsquo sowing and have been appreciated for their colourful display by both local residents and visitors.ldquoSome of the wildflower sites in East Lothian form part of the John Muir Pollinator Way, which aims to create habitat for pollinators along the entire -mile route of the John Muir Way.ldquoThis initiative, developed by Bugle UK, identies where wildflower forage and nesting habitats for pollinators and other wildle can be created, enhanced and managed along the John Muir Way, including on school grounds, golf courses, cemeteries and public parks, and included wildflower sowing at Prestongrange Museum last year.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoIt is stunning and has really taken off this year. Anything which involves wildflowers is gorgeous.The golf ball-shaped sphere, made of hundreds of horse shoes, is one of two sporting sculptures commissioned by the community council for the townrsquos gateways, depicting the townrsquos golf and horse racing heritage. Sculptor Ronnie Elliot designed the golf ball, while artist Kenny Munro created a steel sculpture of three race horses at Newhailes.

title: former-mens-club-become-four-flats
story: East Lothian Council has given the green light to East Lothian Propertyrsquos plans to transform  Sidegate.The former Haddington Recreation Club closed its doors in the early s and will now become home to a ground-floor office and four flats.The three-storey property is currently used as bedsit accommodation.One member of the public objected to the proposals on grounds including road safety, the likelihood that ldquothe use of the building to accommodate an office and four flats will lead to a large number of cars parking on street at this potentially dangerous spot and that the proposals ldquodo not accommodate any dedicated off-street parking, the consequence of which would result in cars being parked on the narrow road outside the building which would result in dficulties for other road users and would create a road safety hazard.Despite the objections, the plans were given the go ahead, with the planning officer noting that colleagues in the roads services department raised ldquono objection to the plans.Billiards, draughts and table tennis were all played by male members of Haddington Recreation Club before it closed. It also had a licensed bar.

title: artist-explores-coronavirus-minefield
story: Georgina Bown is an award-winning artist and sculptor whose artwork focuses on nautical man-made constructions.She is well known for her work depicting submarines and oil rigs.After lockdown began in March, Georgina found herself isolated with her two children and confined to work at home.She used this time to create a huge charcoal and pastel drawing of sea mines.The work, named lsquoMinefieldrsquo and measuring cm by cm, took her eight days to complete.Georgina said: ldquoI began feeling that we are in an unpredictable lsquominefieldrsquo, dominated by this highly contagious threat.ldquoThis led me to research sea mines ndash not only are they similar to the virus in shape but can be triggered by physical contact, too.ldquoI hope my work will create a consciousness of this delicate situation and how human touch has become a precarious thing.Throughout the eight days it took her to complete the piece, Georgina filmed a time-lapse of herself at work.The video can be viewed on her Facebook page at www.facebook GeorginaBownArtist

title: chef-praises-student-food-initiative
story: Ms Leith, the universityrsquos chancellor, in her latest video to students and staff, praised those behind lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Heartsrsquo, which has distributed more than , meals during the Covid- lockdown to those in need around Edinburgh.The scheme was launched by Lewis McLachlan, an MSc gastronomy student, and involves chefs, students, hospitality business owners and suppliers volunteering to collect food donations and prepare free meal packs.Lewis said: ldquoWersquove built quite a nice community of volunteers and lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Heartsrsquo is helping us feel a sense of belonging and purpose, too.ldquoThese volunteers are people who wanted to get stuck in and help out. Irsquom so proud of each and every one of them.In her video, Ms Leith discusses healthy eating during lockdown and highlights the gastronomy studentsrsquo ldquoenterprise.She said: ldquoI am so pleased with the gastronomy students who have got together to form their little enterprise called lsquoEmpty Kitchens, Full Hearts.rsquoldquoWhat it does is feed people who are desperately in need of a decent meal and I know they will be bringing, not just nutrition, but genuine comfort and joy.She added: ldquoPlease eat properly yourselves. If you eat nothing but junk, you wonrsquot feel really well.ldquoSo try to eat as much fresh food as you can. I know itrsquos dficult to get but donrsquot just reach for the chocolate bars, Irsquom begging you.For more information, go to facebook EmptyKitchens FullHeartsTo view a video of Lewis talking about their hot lunches, go to facebook EmptyKitchensFullHearts videos

title: high-school-students-snap-photography-contest-top-prizes
story: Carla Mulholland and Declan Longmuir were celebrating some picture perfect images after being crowned winners in the Scottish Civic Trustrsquos My Place Photography competition.The national competition encourages budding photographers, aged between four and , to explore the buildings, architecture and archaeology in the places they live, and experiment with using photography as a means of investigation and creative expression.The competition has free entry, and is open to schools, youth groups, clubs and home-educated young people.The theme for submissions in  was water, in celebration of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.Carla, , who is in S at the Prestonpans high school, was the overall winner in the secondary school category for her photograph lsquoAutumn Leavesrsquo.Saskia Hanmer, from Dunbar Grammar School, was highly commended for her picture, titled lsquoTime Delaysrsquo.Meanwhile, S pupil Declan Longmuir was also celebrating.The -year-old won the Young Personsrsquo Choice Award for his photograph lsquoChristmas at Port Seton Harbourrsquo.A spokesman for the school said: ldquoThis is a real achievement for PL, as our photography course is a short course, recently introduced to the curriculum.ldquoCongratulations to both pupils!Each year, winners of the My Place Photography Competition are honoured at a reception and their entries are displayed in a public exhibition.The  reception and exhibition launch, which was planned for April  at Glasgow Doors Open Days festival hub The Lighthouse, has been rescheduled for September this year.Fiona Hyslop MSP, cabinet secretary for economy, fair work and culture, said: ldquoI want to congratulate all of this yearrsquos entrants for the exceptional standard of photography that has again been produced by Scotlandrsquos schoolchildren for the My Place Photography Awards, and the many inventive ways in which they have captured their local built environments.ldquoThe awards are a terric way to stimulate interest and to nurture a concern for our surroundings from an early age, and itrsquos great that we can still enjoy seeing the world through the eyes of our young people, by way of the online gallery this year.

title: survey-reveals-public-support-active-travel
story: The survey found that, since the Covid- lockdown began in late March, many people have been cyclingor walkingfour to seven days a week, mainly for exercise or shopping.Equally, respondents to the survey, which was carried out by the Drem Gullane Path Campaign group, reported a marked drop in their use of private cars and public transport in lockdown.Iain Monk, spokesman for the campaign group, said: ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has seen many more people choosing to cycle and walk for exercise and essential journeys.ldquoThere seems to have been a fundamental sht in attitudes towards travel.ldquoAs our survey results show, because the roads are quieter, residents have been taking advantage of the safer environment.ldquoIt is also clear that people want to keep cycling or walking and expect more active travel choices.ldquoWe need council leaders to make a long-term commitment to invest in permanent infrastructure that will help people cycle and walk safely.Of the  people questioned, the vast majority expressed a desire to continue walkingand cyclingthe same, or even more, once lockdown restrictions are lted.Eighty nine per cent of people canvassed thought that East Lothian Council should signicantly invest more in cycling and walking infrastructure.Dominic Campanile, general manager of The Old Clubhouse bar and restaurant in Gullane, said: ldquoAs a local business, the Old Clubhouse is in no doubt about the positive economic impact of more cycling and walking infrastructure.ldquoThe Covid- lockdown has shown that people clearly want more active travel options.ldquoThat is why our business hopes East Lothian Council will look to the future and invest more in active travel infrastructure.A spokeswoman for the local authority stressed it ldquoremains committed to identying and securing active travel options in East Lothian, building upon previous projects.She said: ldquoWe have delivered a comprehensive path network across the county and, over the past five years, have committed capital funding to sustainable travel options, including the safe link from Gullane to North Berwick.ldquoWe are developing proposals for further projects around East Lothian, and having active travel at the core of local transport infrastructure will be a key priority going forward.ldquoWe are also preparing a bid for funding under the new infrastructure programme Spaces for People, which offers funding and support to councils in Scotland to make it safer for people to walk, cycle or wheel for essential trips and exercise during Covid- restrictions.

title: pipers-cook-storm-local-charity
story: Haddington Pipe Band has linked up with Our Community Kitchen, raising more than pound, to support the group, which is based in the townrsquos bowling club.Alastair Bruce, who is on the bandrsquos board of trustees, was delighted to help out in what were challenging circumstances for both organisations.He said: ldquoWe were obviously going to miss all the events that usually go on at this time of the year.ldquoWe came up with the idea of having performances in our gardens at the regular time of Saturday at noon and to keep playing and cheer folk up.ldquoWe started doing that and got a couple of weeks into it and were aware of what Our Community Kitchen were doing.ldquoWe wanted to support them and their fantastic work.The pipe band, which has been  and  members aged from nine to their s, would usually be performing at galas and civic celebrations throughout the county.However, the coronavirus has led to the cancellation of a number of those scheduled events, with weddings also being shelved due to the global pandemic.Mr Bruce said the pipe band decided to use their weekly performances as a fundraiser for Our Community Kitchen and set up an online fundraising page.An initial target of pound has been shattered, with the fundraising figure breaking through the pound, barrier.Mr Bruce thanked everyone that had donated to the cause and said: ldquoIt is wonderful.ldquoWe are really grateful to everybody that has helped with that.ldquoIt has not just been band members who have contributed but other people, who are aware of what the band are doing.ldquoOur Community Kitchen are really pleased as well and it helps them with their work as well.Our Community Kitchen was formed  months ago, with the aim of tackling social isolation in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward by getting people round the dinner table.However, the group was forced to change its method of addressing the problem when social gathering events were banned in March.Instead, they have delivered more than , piping hot meals, ranging from sausage, mash, stuffing and onion gravy to tuna macaroni and cheese, to people in their homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.Elaine Gale, founder of the group, who are delivering meals four times a week, was delighted with the pipe bandrsquos efforts and thanked them.She said: ldquoEvery Saturday, people play in their gardens or the street and where I live in Fairway, we have got two wonderful pipers and people donate.ldquoThey have raised more than pound,, which is unbelievable.ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled that they are doing that for Our Community Kitchen and we are doing our very best for the local community.ldquoIt is wonderful as well to hear them on a Saturday.ldquoI go out and listen to them and it just makes me feel really, really happy and quite tearful and emotional, to be honest.To support the pipe band and Our Community Kitchen, go to justgiving fundraising secretary-haddington-pipe-band

title: new-position-gives-cctv-dunbar-harbour-go-ahead
story: Dunbar Harbour Trustrsquos plans to mount two cameras on an eight-metre high pole at Lamer Island were originally rejected after East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officers ruled they would draw attention from the battery there.However, a second application has now been given the green light after the trust moved the location of the pole to the other side of a wall.The trust said the Lamer Island CCTV cameras, which have antennas, were required to link up a surveillance system with cameras already at the two harbours ndash Victoria and Cromwell ndash on either side of the battery.The original plan saw the pole placed at the front of Lamer Island. Now it will be installed beside the east wall of the battery.Officers approved an application for planning permission and one for listed building consent as required.The council officerrsquos report on the listed building application said: ldquoIn its location, the proposed pole, whilst visible, would not occupy such a prominent position in front of the battery as did the CCTV camera recently refused planning permission and listed building consent.ldquoInstead, it would be seen alongside and in relation to the east wall of the Lamer Island Battery which would provide some screening for the proposed pole.The Lamer Island Battery is an th-century lsquoD-planrsquo bastion of squared sandstone rubbleconstruction with pierced embrasure ornament openings, listed as being of specialarchitectural or historic interest, Category B.It was built as a civil defence outpost and hassubsequently had ious uses, including as an infectious diseases hospital in the th centuryand a military hospital during the First World War.Dunbar Harbour Trust has carried out work to bring the battery back to le and provide accessto it for all.It is currently in use as an interpretationbuilding and amphitheatre.The trust had applied for CCTV planning permission to ldquoaddress requests from the fishing community and generally improve safety and security coverage around the harbour.

title: baking-boys-boost-day-centre-funds
story: William and Alfie Pleasance took it upon themselves to hold a bake sale for the East Linton facility.Generous neighbours on the villagersquos Bank Road did their bit and bought the cakes, helping the duo raise pound.Lynton Day Centre had to temporarily shut its doors when lockdown restrictions were brought into place in March.Since then, staff at the day centre have provided a daily delivery service of a three-course meal to their clients and other vulnerable people in the village.A spokeswoman for the centre said: ldquoTo minimise the risk of spreading Covid- while delivering the meals, we have a strict infection control plan in place.ldquoThis involves using disposable materials for the distribution of the meals.ldquoWe are using the more expensive, compostable food containers and paper bags, so all items can be recycled.ldquoTo cover the extra cost towards this, we had some very generous donations from our community.

title: racing-gets-green-light-return
story: Musselburgh Racecourse will stage the first of five meeting on the last day of the month with fixtures also planned for Wednesday, July .They will be followed by fixtures scheduled on Friday, July , Thursday, July , and Wednesday, August .The first race in Scotland since the Covid outbreaktakes place at Ayr this Monday .It is expected other fixtures will be assigned by the British Horseracing Authority in due course to Musselburgh and Scotlandrsquos other four racecourses.Musselburghrsquos management team hasestablished procedures for hosting controlled meetings without spectators which meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards and have been working closely with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland in preparation for the resumption of racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, welcomed the announcement and said Scottish racing was fully prepared to play a vital role in supporting owners, trainers and the wider horseracing sector.He said: ldquoControlled horseracing meetings have been very successfully introduced in England, Ireland and a number of other countries and we are looking forward to playing our part in getting the wheels of the industry turning again in Scotland.Racing fans will be able to follow the action through a number of dferent options, including live screening on Racing TV, ITV Racing, on catch up via Racing TV Player, and through bookmakers websites for those who have accounts.Joe FitzPatrickMSP, minister for public health,sport  wellbeing, said: ldquoIrsquom sure that this news will be welcomed by racing fans across the country. The resumption of professional sports is another step towards some level of normality and its safe resumption is only possible thanks to a constructive relationship between the Scottish Government and bodies like Scottish Racing.Delly Innes, manager of Scottish Racing, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome theof racing in Scotland after a long, but necessary, absence as Scotland faced the challenges of Covid-. This has been an immensely challenging time for our five excellent racecourses, but this is an important first step on the road to recovery, and we will be working hard to ensure all our participants are familiar with, and adhere to Scottish rules and guidance where these dfer from UK guidance.ldquoWe are raring to go with an exciting programme of fixtures in the months ahead which will help support the wider Scottish and British racing industry, and provide entertainment to viewers across the country.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-musselburgh-ormiston
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at four of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS across East and West Saltoun, Humbie and Bolton continue to help and look after each other and plans are being made for how the effort will continue, once volunteers start going back to work.Derek Smith, the single point of contactin West Saltoun, said that people in the area were ldquocarrying on doing as we do and continued to look after each other.For example, two households will do the shopping for another four, and residents from another village have been delivering logs to those who need them.Derek said: ldquoWersquove been helping each other out.ldquoThe number of people in the village who need shopping, or those sheltering and so on, will continue [getting support] as long as itrsquos needed.ldquoIn a village this size, we all know each other, andanyone needs something they can knock on someonersquos door. There is always someone they can get in touch with.Considering how the effort will continue now restrictions are starting to ease, Derek said: ldquoThings may well change as people go back to work. There may be a drop of capability and volunteers able to continue on some basis.He added that the local resilience plan has been updated to include a pandemic, should one happen again in the future. Plans were previously prepared for bad weather, such as the snow seen in the lsquoBeast from the Eastrsquo.In Humbie, the first weekly soup-and-sandwich lunch was delivered last Wednesdayto local residents who are isolating or severely restricting their movements.The aim of the lunch is to provide some socially distanced contact and something for residents to look forward to each week.Al Beck, from Humbie, East  West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, said: ldquoEverything looked great and the lunch, together with the brief visit by our volunteers, was warmly received by everyone.The project is planned to run for the next approximately eight weeks.One resident said: ldquoThank you all for the lsquosouperrsquo lunch, we really enjoyed it. Had a lovely wee chat with the lady who delivered.Another said: ldquoThank you all, my mum enjoyed her lunch and apparently was going to share her scone, but decided to eat it all herself as she said it was too good to share.Those who live in the Humbie and Fala area and are interested in the soupand-sandwich lunch, either for themselves or for someone  they know, are encouraged to get in touch with Margo Hodge.For those needing assistance, people in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aolEast Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahooIn West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmailIn Humbie, residents are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMusselburghGARDENING tools are on loan through Resilient Musselburgh during the Covid- crisis.They have been provided by the Musselburgh Tool Library and everything from strimmers, lawn mowers, edgers, hedge trimmers, hoes, rakes, spades and forks can be borrowed.Tools can be booked by calling the Musselburgh community response phone line on  .They will be delivered direct to householders on a Friday morning between .am and .am and collected at the same time the following week.Jane Cummings, from East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities, said: ldquoThis is a temporary service to help people maintain and enjoy their gardens during the summer months. There is no charge but tools must be booked in advance.Resilient Musselburgh also submitted a short video competition entry to Nisarsquos charity lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo on how it spent the companyrsquos pound donation, which was received in May.This video has won an award of an additional pound, towards the community response in Musselburgh, Whitecraig, Wallyford and Old Craighall.Resilient Musselburgh is being led by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership, helped by an army of around  volunteers.It is continuing to deliver food and prescriptions to vulnerable people in the area during the coronavirus crisis.OrmistonTHE Pennypit Community Development Trust has put out an appeal for supplies of groceries, toiletries, and other items to help them continue supplying surrounding communities during the ongoing lockdown.Ormiston Community Council said it received a fantastic response after sharing the appeal on Ormi Folks Facebook page, with several volunteers collecting donations and delivering them to St Martinrsquos Hall to be distributed.Councillors thanked everyone who contributed to the appeal.The community resilience team is currently assessing the way forward, with some volunteers now ing to work and the likelihood that some of those who needed help during the first phase of lockdown may not need as much support as the easing of restrictions continues.Scott Gillies, community council chairman, said: ldquoWe are now assessing how things will continue now that some volunteers are ing to work, and also some who were needing help during the initial lockdown period may not need as much assistance.ldquoWe feel we still have adequate cover to continue the food deliveries, carry out shopping and pick up prescriptions for the time being.If anyone in Ormiston requires help they can contact the team on   between am and pm, seven days a week, or email Ormistonrcrteam@hotmail

title: roadworks-close-part-a1
story: The eastbound carriageway between the Gladsmuir junction and Oaktree junction, near Haddington, will be closed from pm tomorrow until am on Thursdaywhile work is carried out.A ersion will be put in place and signposted, taking people via the B, A through Gladsmuirand then onto the B into Haddington.The following night , the westbound carriageway will be closed from Gladsmuir to the Bankton junction, north of Tranent,from pm on Thursday night until am on Friday morning .A ersion will take people on the A, which passes through Tranent.The works, which are described by operating company Amey as ldquoessential, are estimated to cost about pound,.Amey said the work will ldquoimprove safety and reduce overall maintenance costs by mitigating the need for further reactive repairs.Work is being completed by a contractor on behalf of Amey and Transport Scotland.While the work is being carried out, physical distancing will be in place to ensure all staff on site remain safe.Thorough risk assessments will be carried out and cleansing stations will also be put in place on site.For more information visit scottishtrunkroadsse-live.amey a overnight-roadworks-on-the-a--juneor East Lothian Councils website and Facebook page.

title: 1-650-spent-remind-residents-keep-distance
story: The ft-high information boards have been produced to remind people to follow social distancing rules as restrictions on outdoor gatherings are eased.With the message Keep East Lothian Moving, the boards remind people to maintain a two-metre distance and "consider others when youre out and about".The messages are accompanied by images of people out walking their dogs, with their families, running and cycling and an elderly person using a walking aid, as well as a skateboarder.East Lothian Council said it had invested more than pound, in the boards which will appear across  key sites.The move comes as the local authority also deployed mobile electronic signs on the A coast road over the weekend reminding people to stay local.The electronic signs, usually used to deter speeding on the road, changed its message as the council reopened its larger coastal car parks for local residents to use.They warned people not to stray too far from their home comforts with the message, Stay Local No Public Toilets.A council spokesperson said the new social distance boards would be placed at sites around the county.They said: ldquoAt this stage, we have identied  locations in dferent parts of East Lothian where these materials, highlighting the importance of physical distancing guidelines, will be put in place."Thirty copies have been ordered at a cost of pound,.

title: headteacher-praised-leadership-style
story: North Berwick High Schools head Lauren Rodgerwas described by Education Scotland inspectors as having a clear direction and being well respected.However while the inspection, carried out in February,praised the staff and leadership at the school and achievements of its senior students, it pointed to improvements required to enable more S-S pupils to learn a foreign language.The report called for more work to be done to ensure all younger students received their full entitlement to Broad General Educationin the first three years at the school.In particular it stated: "Currently, a few young people are not experiencing a modern language until the end of S."Inaddition, the current arrangement is not sufficient for young people to receive their entitlementto a meaningful experience of a third language."Inspectors urged the school to ensure the focus was on ensuring younger pupils received full access to experiences across the curriculum and did not allow a focus on reaching exam levels to impact on them.The inspectors said: "Teachers should ensure that learning at Sacross all curriculum areas remains focused on the experiences and outcomes of CfEanddoes not prioritise the requirements of National Qualications ."Senior and middle leadersshould ensure that learning experiences in S provide those young people specialising atfourth level with appropriate depth in their learning to provide successful progression to thesenior phase."Inspectors visited the school in February  and assessed the schoolrsquos performance across four key indicators: leadership of change learning, teaching and assessment raising attainment and achievement and ensuring wellbeing, equality and inclusion.The school was evaluated as lsquovery goodrsquo in the first three categories and lsquogoodrsquo in the fourth.Headteacher Lauren Rodgerrsquos leadership style was described as ldquocharacterised by openness and by trust, promoting empowerment in a supportive ethos. Inspectors highlighted the strong leadership at all staff levels and the use of effective research to support creative learning.Innovative approaches to teaching and assessment encourage young people to take responsibility for their own learning. Where young people are facing personal challenges, the report noted that targeted strategies are used to support them, and an open climate exists within the school around mental health.As part of the process, inspectors make recommendations for areas of improvement. The letter outlines recommendations that the school continues with its improvements to the planning process for S-S and reviews its approaches for checking on pupilrsquos wellbeing.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, East Lothian Councils cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate Lauren Rodger and her team on a very positive report. The inspectorsrsquo comments regarding strong leadership and how this supports pupilsrsquo attainment through creative learning and personal responsibility is a real testament to the school teamrsquos positive work and ethos."Thisreport will provide confidence and comfort for parents and carers, and is much-welcomed good news for the school community.Lesley Brown, chief operating officer for education at the local authority, said: ldquoIrsquom sure this report will be welcomed by everyone connected with North Berwick High School."Irsquom especially pleased to see inspectors recognise the work that staff and pupils have undertaken to open-up conversations around mental health and wellbeing."This will be especially important in the months ahead as weto school, and is very much in line with our approach to use nurture to help reconnect and recover from Covid. Irsquod like to commend Lauren Rodger and her team on their achievements and their commitment to creating such strong learning opportunities.

title: staycation-five-scotlands-photogenic-places-visit-lockdown-eases
story: After exactly three months of lockdown things are starting to look up ndash and just last week it was revealed Scotlandrsquos tourism sector ndash including hotels, pubs and restaurants ndash could reopen from July .And with our beautul scenery, immersing history and friendly locals, therersquos no wonder why some research shows more than half of Brits are eyeing up a lsquostaycationrsquo this year rather than opting to go abroad.With that in mind, wersquove detailed outfiveof the most photogenic lsquostaycationrsquo locations to visit in Scotland once lockdown measures are eased.Harris, Outer HebridesWhen thinking about a lsquostaycationrsquo in Scotland, itrsquos understandable that a beach holiday isnrsquot the first thing on your mind.But the Outer Hebrides beaches are some of the most beautul in Europe ndash and it would be hard to blame youyou thought it was somewhere in the Caribbeanhellip perhaps only the temperature would give it away.In March, Luskentyre Bay on Harris was named as one of the top  beaches in the world by Tripadvisor.The far-flung, sandy outpost - which is reached by a single track road - was rated higher than sun-soaked destinations in Spain, the Caribbean, and the golden shores of Florida to take th spot in the prestigious s Travellers Choice Awards.Described by the sites visitors "as close to heaven as you could get", the expanse of Luskentyre Bay sits on the South of Harris, close to the isolated island of Taransay, where the seminal BBC reality series Castaway  was filmed.Tobermory, MullIt doesnrsquot take a tourism expert to identy the colourful harbour-front buildings of Tobermory from the popular childrenrsquos TV show Balamory.The capital of Mull, Tobermory is arguably one of the prettiest ports in Scotland thanks to the before-mentioned colourful houses and sheltered bay.Legend has it that Tobermory was the location of the sinking of Spanish Armada ship in , carrying gold bullion.You can find out all about the history of the area in the Mull museum ndash orgolf is more of your fancy then therersquos a nine-hole course sitting in the clfs above the bay.The ldquotough challenge offers panoramic views across to the Ardnamurchan Peninsula and, on a clear day, the Isle of Skye.The bay is also a departure point for whale watching and wildle cruises.Eilean Donan, HighlandsItrsquos the most photographed castle in Scotland and has been featured in blockbuster films including James Bond.Recognised around the world as one of the most iconic images of Scotland, itrsquos little wonder the castle is now one of the most visited attractions in the Scottish Highlands.Strategically located on its own little island overlooking the isle of Skye, the castle sits where three lochs ndash Loch Duich, Loch Long and Loch Alsh meet.Surrounded by the mountains of Kintail, visitors have the chance to wander around the internal rooms of the castle while also taking in the wonderful wildle that surrounds the island too ndash with porpoise, dolphins, otters and birdle sightings an often occurrence.Arran, North AyrshireThe Isle of Arran is often described as ldquoScotland in Miniature, soyoursquore looking for a quick staycation but with a lot to experience then look no further.The ever-changing coastline, dramatic mountain peaks, sheltered beaches and tasty local produce makes a holiday in Arran unforgettable.Donrsquot forget to pack your camera ndash with the stunning views of and from the islandrsquos largest mountain, Goatfell, worth capturing.Not only that but the island boasts a wealth of nature, including red squirrels, deer, golden eagles, otters, seals and basking sharks just waiting to be snapped up.Glenfinnan Viaduct, HighlandsMade ever more popular by the Harry Potter films, the Glenfinnan Viaduct attracts thousands of visitors from across the world every year.The special atmosphere and the stunning scenery overlooking the famous railway track makes for some magical images ndash no wonder why they chose it for the wizarding films.The famous viaduct carries the railway to Glenfinnan station across a ft span, ft above the ground ndash and the Jacobite steam train runs from here to Fort William and Mallaig in the summer months.Visitors are reminded, however, that trespassing on the railway line is extremely dangerous and they should stay clear of the tracks at all times.Full details of all the locations and more are available on Visit Scotlands website here.And remember: Do not travel for leisure until the Scottish Government guidance says it is acceptable to do so.

title: bbc-tv-licence-payments-75s-delayed-october
story: It comes after anational newspaper reported earlier thisweek on theintroduction of mandatory TV licences for over s - suggesting they would be making them pay the annual charge ofpound.from this October, rather thanAugust.However, the BBC have quickly moved to clary the situation.What have the BBC said In relation to an article published in the , aBBC spokesperson said: ldquoThe BBC has made no such decision and it is wrong to suggest we have."The BBCs position is that we have delayed implementation until August - and we are doing what we have always said - which is keeping that decision under review."The BBC will announce its decision in July."Why were the plans delayed Initially, over-s would have had to begin paying in June, but plans were pushed back to August in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.TV licenses were deemed necessary in keeping over-s - who are more at risk from the effects of Covid- - informed as the pandemic spread.Chairman of the BBC, Sir David Clementi, said at the time: "The BBC board has decided to delay changes to over s licence fees."We are in exceptional circumstances. Now is not the right time. We are fully focused on delivering our services to the public at this dficult time."Reaction to the moveLord Foulkes, the chairman of the All-Party Group for Ageing and Older People, said: "The Government should cover the cost as a social benefit and not burden the BBC, which is already strapped for cash."We will continue to work on this vital campaign alongside the likes of Age UK, as well as a growing number of MPs and peers."Caroline Abrahams, the charity director at Age UK, added: "While many older people are being advised to stay mostly at home, or are too worried to go out, free TV licences for over-s should continue."The last thing they need is to have to get to grips with a new TV licence scheme, or risk prosecutionthey get it wrong."When were free TV licences for over s introduced Free TV licences for over s were introduced by Labour PM Gordon Brown, and were first paid for by a Labour government in .

title: can-move-home-scotland-rules-need-know-measures-eased
story: During her announcement of Phase  on June , the First Minister revealed that restrictions on the housing market will be relaxed from June  ndash this coming Monday.That announcement, according to ESPC, sparked a rise in demand for property in Scotland ndash with viewing requests, home report and schedule downloads at the highest level theyrsquove been since pre-lockdown.Here, wersquove collated some of the key guidance from the Scottish Government ahead of the changes on Monday ndash in a bid to make moving home as smooth as possible during the lockdown.What do I need to know From June , all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.Under what circumstances can I leave my home While in normal circumstances, under current guidance you are only allowed to travel more than five miles to visit family or friends.But these rules do not come in to force when done in connection with the purchase, sale, letting or rental of a residential property.The activities allowed under those rules are:Also, under the guidance published on Tuesday, people working for relevant organisations and businesses in the housing sector can also travel to work where necessary to undertake these activities in a safe manner.What changes will remain The Scottish Government has said that the process will ldquonot be ato normality, and instead said it ldquowill have to adapt practices and procedures to ensure the risk of the spread of COVID- is reduced as far as possible.This includes more of the process going online ndash for example virtual viewing and valuations where possible.The following measures should be followed:What  should I know The Scottish Government advice says that surveyors should not enter a property where a member of the household is showing symptoms of COVID- or self-isolating.When moving your belongings, it is worth remembering that removal firms are able to operate ndash however you may wish to make your own arrangements to move belongings.The guidance also encourages everyone to be as flexible as possible during this period and be prepared to delay moves ndash for examplesomeone has to self-isolate or falls ill during the moving process.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.#

title: laughing-gas-canisters-found-discarded-longniddry-bents
story: Users ndash who usually inhale the gas using a balloon ndash get a temporary high but can become panicky and confused.During a clear up of Longniddry Bents last week,  discarded canisters were found, alongside hundreds of empty alcohol bottles.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell,the local area police commander, has warned of a trend among young people of nitrous oxide use and urged parents to speak to their children about its dangers.The father-of-two said it was ldquoextremely concerning and told the Courier: ldquoInhaling the gas slows downmessages between the brain and body, causing temporary feelings of calmness and joy.ldquoNegative effects can include dizziness, headaches or fainting. It can also cause confusion and cloud judgement. Sometimes the user can see or hear things that arenrsquot real.ldquoThe risks include it preventing the ability to breathe and, in extreme cases, death.ldquoIt can cause the heart rate to beat irregularly, increasing the risk of heart failure and heavy use has been linked to vitamin B deficiency which can cause nerve damage.ldquoAs well as these, the user can become confused and panicky which may lead to accidents.The gas is not illegal and can be bought widely online and is used by dentists and medical professionals to sedate patients for minor medical procedures.The officer stressed it was ldquonot something we want our children and young people experimenting with.A spokesperson for Midlothian and East Lothian Drugs and Alcohol Partnershipsaid: ldquoWe would like to remind the public that laughing gas might sound fun, but the risks are not.ldquoNitrous oxide slows down messages between the brain and body.ldquoNegative effects can include dizziness, headaches or fainting and dficulty in your ability to breathe.ldquoIt can also cause confusion and clouded judgement.ldquoThis may put you at higher risk of accidents.ldquoIt is best to avoid using nitrous oxide, especiallyyou have an underlying health condition and mixing it with other drugs, particularly alcohol, increases the risk of harm.ldquoAnyone seeking further assistance, support or advice is advised to contact MYPAS who provide a friendly, confidential and nonjudgemental drug and alcohol support for young people in East Lothian and Midlothian.Sharon Saunders, head of communities and partnerships at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe have had reports of the misuse of these canisters from a number of council services including Safer Communities, Countryside Rangers and MELDAP and, as leaders of services for children and young people, we are all concerned that people know of this developing trend and the signicant risks associated with use of these canisters.ldquoUsing these canisters poses signicant health concerns as itrsquos a harmful and potentially lethal substance and itrsquos important that young people and their families are aware of the real and signicant health risks associated with using these canisters.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, and Iain Gray, the countyrsquos MSP, backed plans for a multi-agency meeting to tackle the issue.Mr MacAskill said: ldquoOne of the main problems in this case is one of supply.ldquoThe substance can feel quite easy to get hold of, but this is absolutely no indicator that it is safe.ldquoIt is extremely dangerous, especially for those with undiagnosed or asymptomatic illnesses.ldquoYoung people who are abusing it are taking huge risks themselves and for their friends as well.ldquoOne of the problems is that there are legitimate uses for the capsules, especially in the catering industry.ldquoThere needs to be a well-rounded approach to tackling this latest trend, involving education, support from the police and responsible vendors.Mr Gray was similarly keen to see the issue tackled and encouraged anyone with information to contact the police.He said: ldquoThere have been widespread reports of large numbers of these discarded canisters being found in areas across the UK over recent weeks.ldquoThe fact that so many were found in one place here suggests that this is also a problem locally and one that will undoubtedly be of concern to parents.ldquoIrsquom pleased to see that a multiagency response is being pursued to help tackle the issue, and would certainly echo what has been said about parents discussing the potential risks with their children and reporting any relevant information to the police.Ch Insp Mitchell urged parents, writing in his Courier column: ldquoPlease do all you can to talk to your children, discuss the dangers of these canisters and of the impact of anti-social behaviour.ldquoEventhey havenrsquot been part of the group, they may know who has been and please report any concerns to us on the  number or  in an emergency.ldquoIf we all work together we can improve our communities and keep our children and young people safe.

title: chester-takes-reins-musselburgh-racecourse
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that a contract handing operations of the course to Chester, who will operate the course as Musselburgh Racecourse Ltd,was signed earlier today.The racecourse ndash which is on Common Good land ndash was put out to tender for third party operators in  after a troubled history surrounding its management committee saw the British Horseracing Authority demand an independent review of its governance.A new Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee was established with four elected councillors and two representatives of Lothians Racing Syndicate, to oversee the transfer to new operators.Chester wasnamed as the preferred bidder in October last year but negotiations were delayed by the coronavirus crisis.The handover comes just days before Musselburgh welcomes theof racing with its first fixtures being held behind closed doors on Tuesday, June  and Wednesday, July .Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, MRAC chairperson, said: ldquoI welcome the completion of the transfer of Musselburgh racecourse to the new operator, Musselburgh Racecourse Limited, part of Chester Racecoursersquos group of companies."I want to thank all the members of the Musselburgh Racing Association, and its predecessor, MJRC, for their contributions over the years, both councillors and representatives of the LRS."It is their work and the staff team which has transformed the racecourse into a five star visitor attraction."I look forward to a positive working relationship with the new operators as we move forward into this new chapter in the history of the racecourse, to the benefit of everyone involved, the community of Musselburgh and the wider East Lothian economy

title: aldi-asda-tesco-sainsburys-m-s-update-face-mask-rules
story: It comes after the UK government released guidance in May regarding the wearing of masks in both essential and non-essential shops.Currently, it remainsoptional as to whether they should be worn inside shops and supermarkets. But the major chains have put their own guidance in place.What is the latest government guidance The government guidance says: "If you can, wear a face covering in an enclosed space where social distancing isnrsquot possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet.ldquoThis is most relevant for short periods indoors in crowded areas, for example on public transport or in some shops.Many shoppers have since taken the decision to wear masks in stores.Weve put together a round-up of what the rules are on face masks from all of the major title: queen-margaret-universitys-catering-team-delivers-tasty-results
story: BaxterStorey, the universityrsquos catering services partner, has been helping charities and community groups.Julie Smith, general manager, and her team have been operating a pop-up shop and takeaway from Maggiersquos Bar and Cafe in the Studentsrsquo Union throughout lockdown, keeping students and local residents stocked up with essential household items.They also joined forces with the Studentsrsquo Union, student support service ResLe, and the University and College Union branch to put together  wellbeing packs for students living in university accommodation.And BaxterStorey and the university have been supporting Empty Kitchens, Full Hearts, a social enterprise which produces packs of hot meals, fruit and vegetables for vulnerable groups.Davie Beattie, one of the BaxterStorey chefs, has been helping to cover shts in the kitchen at the Carberry Residential Home near Musselburgh.A university spokesperson said: ldquoDaviersquos support has been invaluable at this time due to some of the homersquos kitchen staff being in the shielding group or having to self-isolate.Julie said: ldquoI feel incredibly privileged to have such a committed and passionate team and to have been afforded the opportunity to support the local community.Sarah Whigham, acting head of commercial services at QMU, said: ldquoIrsquom so proud of everything that Julie and the BaxterStorey team have done to help the local community in these challenging times.

title: poignant-picture-tribute-paid-mark-mens-day
story: Co-op Funeralcare invited families to send in photos of their fathers or other male loved ones they wanted to remember and pay tribute to.The images were used in a montage that filled the windows of its High Street shop on Sunday, which it renamed Menrsquos Day.The memorial window was created by the Co-op team, who hoped it would offer comfort to those who have lost someone and wanted to remember them, at what staff members said could be a dficult time of the year.Lee Stewart, funeral director at the Tranent branch, said: ldquoWe recognise that, even though your dad, or any male figure, may not be here any more, you still think of him every day.ldquoFatherrsquos Day is a wonderful celebration but it can be a particularly dficult and poignant time for bereaved families, especially considering the current climate.ldquoWe thought the window would be a lovely way to symbolise how united Tranent is during the pandemic, as well as honouring every dad and male figure who has sadly passed away, hence why we decided to call it lsquoMenrsquos Dayrsquo instead of Fatherrsquos Day.ldquoWe have been inundated with pictures from families, which has been incredibly heart-warming to see.It is not the first time the team in Tranent has used the shop windows to mark special occasions and pay tribute.In November last year, a display in honour of the countyrsquos war heroes and recognising their sacrices was created, with medals, ration books, memorabilia and other tributes on show.Lee said: ldquoWe take pride in our funeral home being at the very heart of the local community.ldquoEvery day, our staff work extremely hard to assist families during these very dficult times, and wersquore always on hand to comfort and support families throughout the bereavement process.

title: seabird-centre-boosted-limited-edition-puffin-prints
story: Creature Candy, based in Warwickshire, has been selling limited edition puffin prints, with a third of the money from each sale going to North Berwickrsquos Seabird Centre.The campaign has been endorsed by Nick Baker, a TV presenter and naturalist.Lizzie Barker, founder and director of Creature Candy, said: ldquoWe want to do our bit to ensure the centre can continue its important, extremely valuable work.ldquoWe are proud to support a number of wildle charities and important conservation projects.ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre provides a wonderful environment for the public to enjoy and learn about seabirds and other marine animals.ldquoIt also plays an important role in the conservation and protection of some of the most fragile habitats on the planet.ldquoIts survival is imperative and we sincerely hope we can help to make this happen.Each print costs pound and a goal of pound, from sales has been set, which would mean more than pound, being donated to the Seabird Centre.Creature Candy is halfway through its campaign, and aims to run it for another two weeks.For more information, visit www.crowdfunder puffin-prints-to-help-save-scottish-seabird-centreSusan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, said: ldquoWe were delighted to be approached by Lizzie from Creature Candy, as they have a good reputation for raising funds for UK wildle charities.ldquoTheir puffin print resonated well with us as the puffin is one of the main attractions people usually flock to see in the Firth of Forth at this time of year. It also is emblematic for our award-winning SOS Puffin project.ldquoWe hope that people will value buying a product that has such strong ties with the centrersquos activities and that will be contributing to our overall public fundraising appeal.The Seabird Centre launched its public appeal last month, aiming to raise pound, to save it from closure due to the financial impact of Covid-. So far, more than pound, has been collected.

title: publics-last-chance-view-early-plans-dunbear-park
story: Retail and leisure units, drive-thru units, a hotel, offices, a nursery, care home and elderly amenity flats, as well as industrial and storage units, would be created on the site, which is to the rear of the towns Asda store.An innovation centre, to assist in accelerating the business growth of entrepreneurs, business start-ups and SMEs, is also included in the plans, which feature  low carbon affordable homes for rent.The new homes on the -acre site would be aimed at key workers, such as NHS staff, police and care workers.An online presentation took place earlier this month, which gave people the chance to see the proposals for DunBear Park for the first time.The scheme, which is based around the DunBear sculpture, would see ldquoa mixed-use development created.Ken Ross, from applicants Hallhill Developments Ltd, was pleased with the turnout at the exhibition, which took place online as social gatherings were cancelled due to the coronavirus.He said: ldquoWe are incredibly grateful and would like to thank those who took the time to participate in the digital consultation event for the low carbon community we are proposing at DunBear Park.ldquoWith more than , visiting the website to date we are delighted with the response we have received so far, which has surpassed our expectations.ldquoWe are encouraging residents to participate in the consultation process by visiting our virtual exhibition at www.dunbearpark planning before this Friday to find out more and offer feedback on the plans.ldquoWe will use this information to shape our development proposals for this area, delivering further sustainable economic growth and creating new job opportunities.ldquoWhat are seeking to deliver is an exemplar development, which not only Dunbar, but East Lothian and Scotland can be proud of.ldquoThe support of the community will be crucial in achieving this.Those looking to submit their views should go to www.dunbearpark planning or e-mail hello@dunbearpark

title: clap-schools-mark-end-term
story: Pupils across the county are due to complete their last day of term tomorrow before starting their summer holidays.The event, in East Lothian, is believed to have been started by Dunbar Primary School.Similar to the pm Clap for Carers, this aims to instead thank and pay tribute to all of the school pupils, teachers, staff and their families for the hard work they have put in over the past few months, during what has been a unique and challenging time.In a post on Twitter, Dunbar Primary School said: ldquoAlongside the wonderful video being produced by the Dunbar music school, wouldnrsquot it be wonderful for the whole town to come together to applaud the children, teachers and families that have worked so hard over the last weeks and months.ldquoWhile we canrsquot come together as usual at both campuses to clap out those moving up and moving on ndash itrsquos always such an emotional and uplting event ndash we can do something as a whole community to mark the end of a very unusual and challenging term.ldquoVery much like the Clap for Carers, how about at  noon this Fridayeveryone claps on their doorsteps.ldquoThe school have supported this idea and the staff will
